conversation.content: [surprised] You're the new janitor? But I've seen your handwriting on those supply request forms—that's classical Arabic calligraphy, the kind they don't teach anymore.
Most people here just see a mop and bucket, not the hands that hold them. Yes, I studied calligraphy back home, among other things that don't matter much now.
[gently] They matter. I teach linguistics here, and that script you write—it's beautiful, almost poetic in its precision. Where did you learn such formal techniques?

Damascus University, though that feels like someone else's life entirely. [soft laugh] I taught literature there for fifteen years before the war made poets into refugees and professors into janitors.
[stunned] You were a literature professor? My God, and here you are emptying my trash while I complain about freshman essays. This is—this is completely backwards.
Backwards, forwards, these directions lose meaning when you're grateful just to be alive and working. [sighs] Your trash can doesn't judge my accent or question my credentials.
Your credentials are probably more impressive than half our faculty's. Look, I know the department has some adjunct positions opening up, maybe we could find a way to—
[wistful] You're kind, but my degrees are ashes now, literally burned with the university library. Here, I'm nobody's colleague, just Ahmad who cleans well and stays quiet.
That's not true. Knowledge doesn't burn, Ahmad. If you taught literature for fifteen years, that expertise is still there, still valuable, still needed.
Needed? [bitter laugh] I've sent over two hundred applications using my real qualifications. The only callback I got was for this janitor position.
[firmly] Then the system is broken, not you. Would you consider guest lecturing in my comparative literature seminar? Just one class, talking about Arabic poetry, paid of course.
You want me to stand before your students? They'll see a janitor playing professor, not a scholar sharing knowledge. [quieter] I'm not sure I remember how to be that person anymore.
You never stopped being that person. Every note you leave in perfect calligraphy, every time you reorganize my scattered books by linguistic origin—you're still teaching, just differently.
[slowly warming] You noticed the book organizing? I couldn't help myself; seeing Rumi next to automotive manuals physically hurt me.
[chuckles] I thought I was going crazy! But it made so much more sense your way. Please, one guest lecture. Let me introduce you properly to the academic community here.
One lecture. [exhales] But I choose the topic—not refugee poetry or war literature. I want to teach them about Al-Mutanabbi, about beauty that existed before everything burned.
Absolutely, whatever you want to teach. We'll start with one class and see what happens. Sometimes the smallest door opens onto the largest room.
[voice lifting] There's an old saying—'The ink of scholars is holier than the blood of martyrs.' Perhaps some ink remains in these janitor's hands after all.
More than remains, Ahmad. [warmly] It's been waiting to flow again. How's next Thursday at 2 PM? I'll make sure the department knows exactly who they're hearing from.
[genuinely moved] Thursday at 2 PM. I'll be there, and for once, I won't be carrying a mop. Thank you for seeing what others choose not to see.

scenario: A linguistics professor discovers that the university's new janitor is actually a former literature professor from Damascus, now working the only job his refugee status allows.
